This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4luJP2sGF3i

Up until now I've been using a drill press vice to hold circuit boards during soldering. The problem is that that type of vice is a hard clamp and won't hold the board well unless you squish it hard enough to risk damaging the board.  
So I designed a super simple model based on springs that will effectively hold pcbs firm. I thought about adding some more features but decided that simple was best here.   
Attached is a pdf drawing for those of you who want to make custom jaws.

Print all parts with at least 30% infill, 2 perimeters. The shafts are 5/16" diameter oak dowel rod, 8" long each. The clamp uses (1) 8-32 bolt 2" long with a butterfly nut. The two springs can be any compression spring with an ID slightly above 5/16". The two part A pieces of the vice are identical. To get the fit you need use a 5/16" drill bit to cleanup the holes on the part of the vice that slides.
Use superglue on the other end to keep it in place.

title: Cheerson CX-10 Millennium Falcon prop. guard remix

description.text:
thing:689333 modified so
  • main guard is sturdier (2mm instead of 1)
  • 4 pillars to allow top to be glued
  • top piece to be glued on top of the pillars of the bottom guard
    • This way it looks IMHO better and even if the cx10 drops on the head it will protect the props I wonder if one used some light masking tape and made a thin wall, or if a thin wall was printed completely encompassing the props how would the small kopter behave

Print the bottom part (I printed 0.2mm layer 90% infill), make sure you have properly calibrated machine or the pillars will not print properly, if you print PLA you must have fan cooling the print or the pillars will be a complete mess. The bottom part is 2mm height so make sure you use layer height that will give you whole number of layers for 2mm (for e.g. 0.15mm layer height does not work properly as it is 13.3 layers, 0.2 and 0.25mm layers work perfectly)  
Attach the bottom part to your CX-10. I put a bit of double stick tape between CX-10 and the hole of the bottom guard so it's a snug fit and holds properly and it is easy to remove without any screws and it is not permanently glued if you glue it down  
Print top layer, it is 1mm height so again use the layer height that's appropriate, I use 0.25mm for the top part, it's 4 layers, prints fast.  
Glue to the top layer to the pillars on the bottom guard. I print this with ABS so I use scrap abs dissolved in acetone as a glue but you can use a heated needle to just smelt them together .. if you are printing with PLA that's the best way to glue them together, just smelt them using hot needle (or old soldering iron)  
voila that's it :D  
btw the guard is not light, 3 times heavier then the original!!!! but works great, the flight is more stable then without the guard, the guard protects your device perfectly and looks awesome (I printed using "glow in the dark ABS") .. now being heavy it means the battery will be running out faster!!! if that's a problem just use the original, light, design :)

comments.text: Looks good and connects with the drone well, however is way too heavy and the supports connecting to the drone body mess with the aerodynamics. Never makes it 6 inches off the ground.
comments.author: Anubis2255

comments.text: maybe your printer is not well calibrated or maybe mine printer is underextruding but for me the cx-10 with this guard fly's to the ceiling without a problem :D .. the only thing I noticed is that it's little sluggish compared to without guard and that the batter last ~20% shorter ... but reaching the altitude was definitely not a problem .. what is the mass of the printed guard you have?
comments.author: Anubis2255

comments.text: Does the weight impede flight at all?
comments.author: Zakattacks

comments.text: you definitely feel that it's heavier with this guard on but for me it makes flying easier :D .. it does all the acrobatics with this strapped on so it works nicely, it's just bit more stable ... now this one was printed very thin, if your printer is not properly calibrated and you pour plastic you can make it too heavy to be useful .. but as is it fly very nicely :)

title: battery retainer for Sport Cub RC airplane

description.text:
This is a retainer for the 1300 mah battery supplied with the Horizon Hobby/ParkZone Sport Cub. It captures the battery and the Velcro strap so that it cannot slip out from under the black Velcro strap.  
I had the battery fall out of the airplane while in flight. My guess is that it slipped out from under the Velcro strap and forced open the flexible battery cover door.  
It is important that the retainer captures both the battery and the Velcro strap.  
I have flight tested this through hard maneuvers and it works.  
I could have tried Velcro, but the battery is hanging upside down.

title: Open Beam corner plate with optional foot

description.text:
New open beam component based on OpenBeamUSA's L bracket.
Basically I wanted a one-piece corner unit that mimicked the original design.
The optional foot mounts over the corner hole in the solid face to hive you a 5mm stand off. (sorry about the print quality, I found the extruder was loose on the carriage after this print).
Print it out with two tops, two bottoms and two perimeters at about 30% fill. Seems to be pretty strong.

comments.text: I repurposed this corner bracket to make a rolling workstation for my Prusa i3. Used 2 cheap IKEA tables. Will post the completed pictures.
comments.author: Teqkng

comments.text: Hey there, just ordered some openbeam (but I doubt it will be coming anytime soon as it seems the whole world's supply is out-of-stock).   Anyway, I thought I'd start printing the plastic parts I need now.  Can you explain the logic behind the closed holes on one side (with recessed holes on the outside), and the other sides faces completely recessed with a lip around the edge of the side?  I'm sure there's a good reason for it, but I cant figure it out!
comments.author: SLAM-ER

comments.text:
Yes the inner-most hole is really only for increased strength. This is just an experiment to increase the number of basic building blocks for use with Open Beam, I was thinking of another OB printer but made from standard parts and a corner piece was not available. The outer lip is just for aesthetics and is mimicking the original flat corner plate I was copying. You can see from the printed parts that my printer was playing up at the time too, they should look a lot smoother than the examples here :)
I like your idea of a stopper block, might have to have another look at this.
comments.author: SLAM-ER

comments.text: Well I have just made the changes myself (removed inner-most holes, changed all sides to same style, added stopper-block), so I will upload the remix (or I'm happy to send it to you to put here if you prefer).

comments.text: Yep that's the reason :) Put it up as your own design derived from this one (which is derived from someone else's one ... and so on)

This turns standard square-pin breakaway headers into latching headers. The standard 4-pin size will fit the CD-ROM audio cables like the ones used for the Gen 4 mechanical endstops. I designed a version to print horizontally and one to print vertically. This has nothing to do with mounting options, but you will probably find that one of these is easier to print on your machine than the other.

Print the vertical or horizontal version (tip: the skeinforge Multiply plugin will make multiples, which will also give the parts time to cool and result in better quality). Make sure the cable connector fits and latches correctly, then insert a 4-pin header (number of pins is configurable in the scad files) and glue it in place.

description.text:
Was tired of loading other darth buddha models that wouldn't slice correctly with cura and required support to print.  
Flattened the base of the buddha and modified the head to fit better. Also added a proper chest plate to complete the look.  
Pictures don't do it justice.  
Added a new reduced size version of the model after running it through meshlab.

Finally got around to rebuilding this with a proper Darth Vader bust (non lego-like), again, no need to print with supports. Some of the improvements:
  • The cowl from buddha's clothing now folds back in a smooth bulge on his back, which prints without supports.
  • Added an edge to the chest plate, so it's not a floating box with buttons in it.
  • The bust is built with as little overhangs as possible. The only area that might require it is on the helmet near the eyes. Your printer will vary.
  • Lastly, his light saber lays at the foot of the pedestal. If people ask or if I get around to it, I might have him holding it in hand instead.
    • Overall, this is the Darth buddha to rule them all. Also if you don't have a printer, I am selling them on Etsy. Small Version:
    https://www.etsy.com/listing/575330701/darth-vader-buddha-with-saber-3d-print Large Version:
    https://www.etsy.com/listing/554694326/large-8-darth-vader-buddha-with-saber-3d

No need for supports on the old version (lego-like head). 
Darth with saber, might require some support on the helmet in front of the eyes. Although depending on how your printer handles over hangs.
Make sure infill is about 20% and .4mm skin (2 walls) should work well.

description.text:
RigidBot especific mount for the L-Cheapo laser cutter tool with the MK2 PCB. The mounting holes are 25 mm apart so it can mount directly over the X belt attachment bolts.  
Tested on IAP's OEM single extruder carriage and should work with the Dual Extruder version as well.  
WARNING: Keep in mind that the laser is some 87 mm behind your nozzle so the beam can hit well beyond your Y limit, if you are careless you could cut your Y belt or any cables below the printer bed (the heated bed cable is a prime candidate). You are supposed to use a sacrificial surface between the printer bed and whatever you are cutting and that sacrificial piece should extend more than 87 mm towards the back on the Y direction.

Included a fixed mesh version of the generic MK2 mount as well, since the STL part by spiritplumber have some non-manifold issues that prevent correct slicing.  
The file named "L-Cheapo V2 RigidBot Mount" is the customized one. Printed in PLA with .2 mm layer height and 0.8 mm top and bottom faces (20% infill) to make sure the bottom plate is nearly solid (that's where the mount stability comes from).  
The mounting surface is 1.8 mm thick and should not be a problem with the original M3x8 bolts, but feel free to use longer ones if you want to be extra safe.

title: rp3d Pangu i3 Extruder Motor support strap

description.text: The direct driver extruder mount for the rp3d.com Pangu i3 Wooden Reprap only uses two horizontally separated screw mounts, the weight of the motor can cause the extruder to sit at a slight angle towards the back of the printer at a slight angle. This simple support strap clips around the motor and down around the lower bearing to pull the assembly properly vertical and tight against the X axis carriage. It's important to note that there isn't much clearance when the X axis homes, ensure that the support strap is flush to the right-most edge of the lower bearing holder so it won't contact the left side of the frame when the X homes. I printed at 0.4mm with 15% rectilinear infill in PLA and it seems to be good enough to do the job. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/31WaAzKPh6z

author: muzz64

description.text:
This WIP is a circular hotend fan to fit your Duplicator i3. It works with the 30mm original cooling fan. UPDATE : v2.7 released (testing it again) I'm trying to print some tests but for now it works okay (aka better than original fan duct).
This printed parts are between 0.3 and 0.2 mm layers, 50mm/s, 25% infill and i was printing PLA @195°C.
For the moment, it didn't melt or anything after 2 hours of printing (PLA again, so low temp compared to ABS) and I hope it stays that way !
As soon as I tried printing with Heatedbed ON, it melted a bit, and finally touched the part I was printing, grinding all over it...
=>DO NOT UNE THIS FAN DUCT IF YOU USE A HEATED BED<=
(unless if you print it in ABS or other High temp plastic) I'll try to upload pics of the tests (with/with original/without fan) as soon as I make them ^^. Any remarks will be appreciated, this is my first fan duct ! If anyone could print and compare their solution to mine, i'll be so happy ! PS :
  • V1.6 has a huge opening on the bottom face, and it seems to be too big to create a "flow" of air...
  • V1.7, I did an update with only 9 holes directed from the inner ring to around the nozzle. I'm testing it right now. Better direction but not enough flow.
  • V1.8 : holes all around, works really well !
  • V2.2 : Big modifications, with larger surface on the builplate, and longer channels. Best option at this time. The flow is circular and directed to the platform just under the nozzle.
  • V2.7: NOT CIRCULAR ANYMORE (for questions of intensity of flow, this is a test) and new longer channels ! Trying it right now !
    • The biggest problem I am facing is a swirl/depression (I have no idea what I'm doing ^^) inside the tore where the air is channelled (inside the part).These "airswirls" are blocking some of the holes leaving the new fanduct with less pressure than the original one... I'm still working on it and figuring step by step how airflow goes in the damn thing ^^. Don't hesistate on making comments, trying parts out by yourself and/or giving ideas and solutions :D

comments.text: They are both too restricted to be a real contender, but its still a step above stock. Take some classes or watch some vids on aerodynamics and you'll get a better idea of how to direct airflow and optimize back pressure so it isn't chugging to push air through, while half of it leaks out the blade gap. Generally, stay away from holes. The one good thing here is the static pressure is high and thus the flow in the doughnut version is even, and the small holes make for high velocity jets, but thats now what you want for printing. You need a circular "blade" of air (ideally) around the nozzle, as close to the print surface as possible, and you want to insulate the heater block from the backwash, so its directed out and the nozzle's temp is more stable, especially with high volume fans. You could make a doughnut with a simple ring shaped opening, pointing down, then make sure walls on the interior are sloped and done so as gently as possible, you dont want sharp bents or corners, that created backpressure and uneven airflow. Thats not enough to keep it even, though. You need to offset the hole so the back end (the end opposite the fan / duct, is open more than the front (closer to fan) end. This will force the higher pressure in the front, to the back, and create an even flow. It takes some practice and CAD to get it exact but just an offset in general makes for a better doughnut shroud.

title: ONE GEAR FOR ALL
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
ONE GEAR FOR ALL this library should allow you to create any gear for whatever use.
It aims to create perfect spiral gears with maximum efficiency while optimizing gear placement how it works:
  • define two axii - that's it, you have a gear pair.
    • you may also want to:
  • define the gear ratio
  • define the slip ratio between the two gears (twist) (spiral angle) and the lile
  • define the gear thickness, pressure angle, holes, whatever else you need
    • This is a work-in-progress and more needs to be done, such as:
  • fix TODOs
  • include loxodrome
  • gear body (the solid core)
  • tooth profile
  • write generic wrapper function
    • Some references:
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_bevel_gear
  • http://kitwallace.tumblr.com/post/76273401911/loxodrome-in-openscad
I used the HAND2.0 B2C (brain-to-computer) interface with the D2E (display-to-eye) option. It works quite well I suppose. If you have other suggestions, let me know :-]

comments.author: ipblythe

description.text:
I added a negative-space module to the Thread Library today. This new module will create a negative space version of a thread, taking care of all the clearance calculations for you. All you need to do is pass it the same parameters as the thread it is meant to screw onto.
I also added a module to create a hexagonal nut that screws onto any threaded rod with the same parameters, but as a more interesting example, I chose to demo the new capability with a split lead nut.
Print and clamp the two parts over a lead screw or trapezoidal threaded rod, such as the ones found in many CNC machines, and attach them with two nuts & bolts. 
The lead nut, if it is not allowed to rotate, will be forced in and out by the rotation of the lead screw ... but you all know CNC machines, you understand this already.
The images show the split lead nut, the negative space with the built-in chamfers, and a cut-away view of a hexagonal nut on a rod, to show the clearances.

This demo code is in the same repository as the library:
https://github.com/syvwlch/Thingiverse-Projects/tree/master/Threaded%20Library To make it work, the library must be in the same directory.

author: cristina40

title: To revive a unicorn candle ring

description.text:
A version of my model "To revive a unicorn". This is meant to serve as a candle ring for decorating candles. The model is quite tricky to print though. I had no luck printing it on the replicator or the replicator 2x, but succeeded making several prototypes on a da vinci. The horns easily breaks though... The model is part of a project which explore 3D-printings ability to make art accessible to everyone, everywhere and become an everyday-experience,
as well as its capability to let people rework and remix art and find new purposes and contexts for art pieces. As part of the project I want to encourage you and everyone else to use this model in whatever way you can imagine - Remix it, hack it or just print it and use it as it is, for what you want. And I will highly appreciate you sharing photos, models and other documentation of what you might do whith it, both here and and on Instagram with the hastag #toreviveaunicorn. Thanks :)

title: Part for Range Rover Classic: HRW sleeve 589818

description.text:
Sleeve for heated rear window cables, corresponding to part number 589818. I believe this part is no longer available.  
I ended up making the section squared instead of the original round one. It seems the squared section serves the purpose better. Also tried to fine tune the curvature to fit the purpose, but more can probably be done here.   
I built it in PLA since that is what I had. I have a slight suspicion that PLA may be a bit brittle and not flexible enough for the purpose, but let us see as the months and years progress.   
You may want to build with a brim to prevent warping. I have added two tiny support columns for the little tongue. They should break off easily.

comments.text: PLA will soon melt and distort from the heat from the sun.  Maybe a flexible filament like Ninjaflex would be best for this?
comments.author: mb20music

comments.text: Good point. Will try to report back after a few months of summer use. Ninjaflex may possibly be too flexible, would be good to try, though.

author: bookmake

description.text: Update 18th of January 2016 As a thanks for the massive amount of downloads and feedback, here are updated versions for both sizes and a completely new version (also for both sizes). The files named "H6" are updated from the old version, they have a slightly thicker frame to prevent breaking when the charger is inserted. Some sanding/filing is still required unless you want to scale it up to 101-103%. Hard to say exactly how much, as all printers are slightly different. This version needs support, and maybe a raft (I use rafts). The files named "T1" are completely new. Even smaller than the previous version and needs no support. The cable exits on a slightly higher angle, so it might interfere with some bands, let me know if that is the case and I'll see what I can do. The higher angle makes it so that its flat on your nightstand even without the weight of the watch, or something tacking it down to the surface. My custom 24mm nylon-strap which is rather stiff works fine with this, but any feedback is appreciated. The only finish-work I did was to remove the raft. The 38mm-versions are not tested (as I don't have one), so if they're wrong please let me know as soon as possible. Hope you like it! :) My prints were done at 0,2mm layer height, 3 shells, 8% infill, with raft, support on "H6", none on "T1".

Inspired by the "Nightstand-mode" in watchOS 2, here's a couple of horizontal nightstand-charging-stands... I use some blue-tack on the underside to prevent it from sliding around when I try to shut the alarm up in the morning. Enjoy. :)
Rotate 90 degrees so that the base is flat on the buildplate. 200 micron, 2-3 shells,. Maybe a raft. Support only needed on "H6".

remixed_from.title: Angled Motor Mount 10° Blackout Mini-H Quad 5"

title: Tilt Motor Mount 10° for Nighthawk frame (updated)

description.text:
Those motor mounts are specifically tuned for Emax Nighthawk frame. They have following characteristics:
  • 10deg forward tilt
  • all screw holes are for M3
  • size and screw holes are adjusted for 22-width motors
  • allow use normal motor screws to bolt motors on the mounts
  • needs 4x M3 screws and nuts to install the mount onto legs
    • Tested successfully on:
  • Emax Nighthawk Pro all carbon frame
  • Emax 2204 2300kv motors

UPDATE 27.06.2015: Updated model does not have inward angle anymore. As I found out during testing that this caused unstable yaw in cleanflight. When doing tight turns - more than 90deg - it overshot badly and I could not fix it with different PID controllers or parameters. Now with straight-front tilt the problem is gone. You can use the previous ones to test its specific characteristics but I based on my experience I cannot recommend the design. Now the design consist of 2 slightly different pieces - one for CW another for CCW motor.

title: Model Rocket Toy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: After seeing Landru's "Printable Model Rocket for 24mm Estes D motors" ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8754 ), I really liked the idea of a printable model rocket. However, because I wanted to use it as a display model, the rocket didn't need to have a motor mount or be as large and Landru's. After a couple of hours of designing and a few test prints, here it is! As a bonus, it functions pretty well as a pencil holder. Overall it takes somewhere around 3 and 1/2 hours to print, with each part at about 1 hr, but this will all depend on your printer's speed.

Print out one of each of the following parts: Base.stl, Body.stl, and NoseCone.stl If you end up with a vertical gap on the nose cone, try setting the extra shells in skeinforge to 0. All the parts press fit together, the tension between them should hold the rocket together.

comments.author: Kayelo

comments.text: Airflow seems to be downward, not inward.  What results have you gotten? (I've yet to get my hands on a 40mm fan to try my make of this)
comments.author: Kayelo

comments.text:
The air flow is mostly downward but is bouncing against the part and the bed (at least in the beginning of the print)
As the head is moving, the molten plastic is fastly subjected to fresh air.
For me, the advantage came mostly because I use a more powerful fan, I can have a better tuning of the cooling. If I turn the fan to 100%, it is so strong that it cools down the extruder.

author: tonylgn

title: Bulldog Lite super strong and simple mount for K8200/3Drag

description.text:
This is the strongest (and simplest) mount for Bulldog Lite that you will find. It fits in the original setup, doesn't require you to raise your heated bed as most other do. Not really important, but it is also very fast to print and requires a small amount of filament compared to other mounts. All you need is:
2x M5 20mm length + washer + split washer
2x square nuts (that you already have from your old mount)
2x large zip ties You can do it with only one M5 though, the mount is constructed in such way that it would hold very strong even without any M5's (the NEMA fixates the hold on te rail when inserted), so with only one M5 on top the mount will be immovable even with force. I haven't tried it with Bulldog XL, I don't know how much the added gears weight would be a problem, but I suspect this mount would hold without any problems. You can also use it as a side mount for any other NEMA17.

title: Delta Effector  w. Magnetic joints for E3D V6

description.text: I am building a delta printer (a modified/re-designed Kossel mini) and this is my effector design, which is based on the different ones already out there. My goal was to make it compact and good-looking, and with magnetic joints for minimal backlash. Here is the complete printer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:923830

I printed in PLA, but ABS is preferred. I would also recommend something like 0.15-0.2 layer height and 100% infill. Parts required:
  • 2x M3x20
  • 2x M3x8/10/12
  • 6x 10mm magnets
  • 6x 10mm countersunk magnets

  • 1x 30mm fan

  • rods with 10mm bearing balls and matching arm carriages

author: hellokatiemalone

description.text:
I made these spacers in order to fit swimming goggles eye cups instead of the black rubber that does not fit my face for these video goggles.
You need to glue everything using hot glue (thicker side of spacer on bottom), and finish by applying large heat shrink tube / black tape in order to isolate from external lights (not shown here).

This is a replacement for the wades_block.stl that is supplied with your M90 by NopHead with a 4mm hole.  
Ordinarily the hole is ~3.2mm for 3mm filament, which is too big for 1.75 and too small for the PTFE.   
This block prints flexibles very well because there is a PTFE liner all the way from the drive gear down into the heat break.
I redesigned the connectors the walls are 3mm thicker, So it is more sturdy. The block is bit more sturdy.

title: IKEA DIODER LED STRIPS - UM mounting kit 45Â° angle

description.text:
My implementation of DIODER (IKEA) strips mounting clips for the ULTIMAKER 3D printer (left / back / right).  
All clips and foots can be mounted left or right because there a similar. For myself I prefer to mirror them respectively simply because the surface looks same viewing from the front.  
The side clips and cable clips are a simple click on / click off system. The back clips (foots) uses the original UM screws. The foots just add two additional mm in height - so you can keep the original screws without having trouble with the length or any need of new screws.  
All clips have an 45Â° angle.  
DO NOT use much force to click in the LED strips in the clips from the front. Just slide the strips from the side into the clips.  
The big STL set with all parts (already mirrored) are exactly what you can see on my photos.  
Happy printing!

comments.text: Just a quick question. Why didn't you also install one on the front side? Also if you place the led strips better, then you won't have to guide the cable beneath the one on the right side.

Based on not just one but two Adafruit designs we've combined the Beagle Bone case with the clip together Raspberry Pi case along with a couple of extra alterations like the hinged lid and improved dragon claws (with inspiration from Deferred Procrastination).

This cover protects the power button which gets easily pressedby accident. It was modelled for the LED Lenser P7 but it can be adapted by changing the parameters.

To generate your own personalized ring you need the MetaCAD AoI plugin - which is still in beta mode. If this does not scare you the plugin can be found here:
http://objects.reprap.org/wiki/Builders/Metalab/AoI_MetaCAD

This is a screw-based connector system intended for use with a modular robotics project. The following formats have been uploaded:
STL
IGES
STEP
Alibre Design (original source) A robot made of components based on this connection system can be seen here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wUivg15i2-Y There is more information in this short paper:
Simple Components for a Reconfigurable Modular Robotic System
which can be found here
https://rpk.lcsr.jhu.edu/Publications#Metamorphic_Robots

This was originally implemented using cast polyurethane, as in this thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:978
but it might work OK when printed. Note: the taper on the pins and the thread angle are both 20 degrees.

comments.text: Any chance you could post these files in STEP or IGES?
comments.author: Gene_Hacker

comments.text: Sure. The original models were done in an old version of Alibre Design. I exported the originals to IGES and two flavors of STEP. These files, and the original Alibre source are uploaded in the new zip archive. The filenames are a little bit different than the STLs, but the models are the same.

Want a easy way to elevate work-pieces off of your laser cutter's
bed? Tired of your projects having char marks on the back because
the laser reflects off of the honeycomb table? The Height-O-Matic is
the solution! Print off as many as you need and place them underneath your
project! Just place them out of the way of your cutting path, focus (I
recommend manually focusing instead of autofocus), and let your
laser do the rest!

I printed these with:
50% Infill
100% Cooling Fan Speed
No support
3 skirt perimeters (To prep the extruder)
MakerGear Natural White PLA Enjoy.

Here's our second scan with the MakerBot Digitizer. We're building the Digitizer to be an affordable, simple 3D scanning tool that fits on your desktop and works perfectly with our MakerBot Desktop 3D Printers. This Garden Gnome shows some great steps toward that goal. Take a look at the detail in the beard and clothes. This is surface detail that we want to be sure to capture, and it looks good here. You'll notice that we printed this file on the MakerBot Replicator 2 at a smaller scale than the original. This is a simple operation in MakerBot MakerWare, our software that processes 3D models to prepare them for printing. Scale up, scale down, no problem. The scan envelope of the MakerBot Digitizer is about eight inches tall, meaning you could print full-height objects on the MakerBot Replicator 2 by turning them on their side. Click here to stay fully up-to-date on the Digitizer progress in our lab, or check out our blog. You can see the full "Digitized!" collection here.
http://store.makerbot.com/digitizer.html
A small folding Chess board that can store pieces internally.

I printed in PLA @ .3 mm layer height.
you need 32 of one color inserts and 32 of another color, just snap them in place. I had to scale one insert at the end to make up for a little warpage with the main board.
Use a pies of wire aprox 1mm in diameter to reinforce the hinge.
Enjoy.

Here's our first scan with the MakerBot Digitizer. We're building the Digitizer to be an affordable, simple 3D scanning tool that fits on your desktop and works perfectly with our MakerBot Desktop 3D Printers. Along those lines, we have some great progress to show you.
We have ears! This has been a real challenge - the trick is how the bunny is positioned on the platform during a scan. We're happy to see two nice ears with no material in between.
The overall shape is captured really well, too, and all the major features - ears, eyes, nose, tail, paws, are well shaped, but not quite perfect.
Click here to stay fully up-to-date on the Digitizer progress in our lab, or check out our blog.
You can see the full "Digitized!" collection here. Note from Bre: I spent a lot of time searching for the ceramic model that Stanford scanned back in the day. After a few years, it popped up on eBay and we made a scan of it.

Ok, once you have an involute gear library AND a trapezoid thread library, you can easily make the simplest of worm drives, i.e. the non-throated kind. Like all worm drives, the gear advances by one tooth for each revolution of the screw but with non-throated ones, there is only a single point of contact at any one time, and so torque and wear capabilities are limited. UPDATE:
As I pointed out in the comments, AFAIK a trapezoidal profile for the worm screw is all you need to match the worm gear's involute. To make them mesh, all I did was to make sure that:
  • the pitch is the same (distance from crest to crest),
  • the pressure angle of the gear is equal to the angle of the sides of the screw profile,
  • the distance between screw and gear is equal to the gear's radial pitch plus the screw's mid-profile radius, and
  • the twist on the gear is equal to the gear's pitch radius divided by the screw's mid profile radius, with a sign depending on the screw's handedness.

This openSCAD script is a demo of the trapezoid thread library but also uses the MCAD involute gears library. It will only work if both of these are in the same directory or in your libraries directory. It is ready for animation, and I have added a GIF of the animation in the comments below. This code is in the same repository as the library:
github.com/syvwlch/Thingiverse-Projects/tree/master/Threaded%20Library

author: ozanbdr

description.text: Tom (a friend of my son) asked me for a boat hull to be equiped with radio command hardware. I started buiding this first trial, to be tested... and continued. It has a helm and a propeller shaft and is waiting to be filled with stuff to be controlled (battery, servos...). It's a relatively large one (more than 27 cm long) and I printed it in diagonal on the bed (I think it's the largest thing I printed on my RepRap Prism. It is a bit bulky (but it floats) and can certainly be improved (you can derive it). You can add a propeller (at the end of the shaft) like the one I found here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15354 (double sized to fit the scale).

1) Print the hull.
  • More than 5 hour for my RepRap Prism (It's a quite slow one, but beware of vibrations that can compromise your correct printing if you decide to speed up).
  • I printed mine in PLA (but it's not ideal to stay a long time in water, because it can disolve).
  • No support needed (I put frames to reduce printing bridges).
  • Relatively low infill (from 15 to 30% I guess).
    2) Print the helm.
    3) Fasten the helm to the hull using a small piece of filament introduced in the holes made in both pieces.
    4) Test the balance and buoyancy
    5) Install hardware to radio-command it (propeller, battery, receiver, servos...).
    6) Test the balance and buoyancy (again with all the stuff installed).
    7) Enjoy !

My team's design for the Makerbot Thingiverse + GE FirstBuild 2015 Hackathon. The theme was to think inside the icebox, so we designed a system for monitoring and controlling distribution of refrigerated medications. For more on the design, it is viewable here: https://firstbuild.com/kaseypackardsmart/fridge-pharm/ All model were designed in solidworks in the span of a day. An arduino Uno was used and we attempted to integrate with firebase. *Note: This model is not by any means refined, having only had a day to complete, so some finishing is required, and the latch and pin were hastily designed so are not included in the available files.

Cool little corner desk based off of the current desk i have in my room. Very simplistic and fun.

5 parts in total  
The desk its self is a 25% infill, you can change it if you would like, doesn't matter. and was printed at .1mm layer height  
There are two types of drawers, the "desk d 2" is the drawer that goes on the bottom, only print one of those, the "desk drawer" are the top 3 drawers, you will need 3 of those. Infill again was at 25% but doesn't matter. and again with a .1mm layer height.  
Oh and remember to print with support!

title: Adjustable Z Endstop for Prusa v2

description.text: Hi Everybody, There goes a good update for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11341 The objective of this piece is to help you to level your print bed z endstop, just turning a single screw. Just don´t hit to hard on the screws that fixes the thing to the prusa as it could break easily.

Hi, 1) Print the 2 stl files. 2) Before installing on the printer, please put the printer on HOME position. 3) Put all the 3 hex nut in the respective nut well of the clip and assemble the plunger with the screws, washers and nuts. 4) Finally try to adjust (slowly) the end stop plunger to trip the endstop switch. 5) Do home bed calibration as very well described at http://reprap.org/wiki/Calibration
